تاریخی سیاق و سباق سے پتہ چلتا ہے کہ اس آیت کو قریش اشرافیہ کو نشانہ بنایا گیا ہے جس نے حضرت محمد (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) کا مذاق اڑایا اور اقتدار اور مادیت سے چمٹے ہوئے قیامت سے انکار کیا۔ شیعہ طافس ، جیسا کہ*المزان*میں الامہ تبتابائی جیسے اسکالرز نے بتایا ہے ، اس بات پر روشنی ڈالی گئی ہے کہ اس طرح کے انکار اکثر تکبر (*استیبر*) اور دنیاوی حیثیت سے وابستگی سے پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ یہ ایک ایسا نمونہ ہے جو ان لوگوں میں دیکھا گیا ہے جنہوں نے نبی کے بعد اہل بیت کی قیادت کی مخالفت کی ہے۔ اس طرح اس آیت کی مذمت ساتویں صدی کے عرب سے آگے ان تمام لوگوں تک پھیلی ہوئی ہے جو جان بوجھ کر لاعلمی یا فعال مخالفت کے ذریعہ خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت خود کی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے: کیا ہم سچائیوں کو مسترد کررہے ہیں۔ اس دور میں جہاں مادیت اور اخلاقی رشتہ داری ایمان کو چیلنج کرتی ہے ، * ال ڈیلون * اور * المکیتھبون * ان لوگوں کے طور پر ظاہر ہوتا ہے جو اللہ سے احتساب سے انکار کرتے ہیں ، انصاف کی ضرورت کو مسترد کرتے ہیں ، یا قرآن اور اہل بیت کے ذریعہ پڑھائے جانے والے دوسروں کے حقوق کو نظرانداز کرتے ہیں۔ عملی طور پر ، اس نے مسلمانوں کو خدائی اصولوں کے ساتھ کام کرنے ، تکبر پر عاجزی کو قبول کرنے ، اور حقیقت کو فعال طور پر برقرار رکھنے کا مطالبہ کیا ہے - چاہے وہ ذاتی طرز عمل ، معاشرتی انصاف ، یا اماموں کی تعلیمات سے وفاداری میں۔ جیسا کہ امام علی (ع) نے سکھایا ، "سچائی بھاری ہے لیکن اچھی ہے ، باطل ہلکا ہے لیکن تباہ کن ہے" - انکار کی آسانی سے زیادہ سالمیت کا وزن منتخب کرنے کے لئے ایک بے وقت یاد دہانی۔
51.layer2_urdu:
سورہ الواقیا (56:51) میں ، آیت "پھر آپ ، پھر آپ ، اے گمراہ [جو] انکار کرتے ہیں" ان لوگوں سے خطاب کرتے ہیں جو اس کے اظہار کے بعد الہی سچائی کو مستقل طور پر مسترد کرتے ہیں۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، جیسے *المزان *میں علامہ تبتابائی ، اس آیت کو سورت کے وسیع تر اسکیوٹولوجیکل فریم ورک کے اندر سیاق و سباق بنائیں ، جو فیصلے کے دن انسانیت کو تین گروہوں میں درجہ بندی کرتا ہے: *سبقون *(عقیدہ میں سب سے اہم) ، *اشعاب ال یامین *(صحابہ *کے ساتھ) ، اور۔ اس آیت نے تیسرے گروہ کو براہ راست سرزنش کی ، جس کی شناخت ان لوگوں کے طور پر کی گئی ہے جنہوں نے الہی رہنمائی سے انحراف کیا اور احل بیت کے ولیہ (خدائی طور پر ترتیب دیئے گئے اختیار) سمیت پیشن گوئی کی تعلیمات کو مسترد کردیا۔ 

تبریسی ، *مجسما البیان *میں ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ یہاں "انکار" محض وہ لوگ نہیں ہیں جنہوں نے حضرت محمد (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) کو مسترد کردیا بلکہ وہ لوگ بھی جنہوں نے اس کی اولاد سے اماموں کی مخالفت کی ، کیونکہ ان کی قیادت پیشن گوئی کے انکشاف کی ایک توسیع ہے۔ یہ شیعہ مذہبی اصول کے ساتھ منسلک ہے کہ اماموں کو پہچاننا توہد (الہی اتحاد) اور نوبووہ (پیشن گوئی) کی تصدیق کرنے سے لازم و ملزوم ہے۔ اس طرح آیت کی مذمت ان لوگوں تک پھیلی ہوئی ہے جنہوں نے سچائی تک رسائی کے باوجود ، اہل بیت کے روحانی اور اخلاقی اختیار کو مجروح کرنے کا انتخاب کیا ، اور اس طرح دونوں غلط فہمی (*دلال*) اور فعال انکار (*تکدیب*) کو مجسم بناتے ہیں۔

مذہبی تبصرے اکثر اس آیت کو اماموں کے * اسما * (عدم استحکام) کے تصور سے جوڑتے ہیں ، اور یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں کہ ان کی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرنا الہی مرضی کی جان بوجھ کر انکار ہے۔ امام جعفر السادیق ، جیسا کہ کلاسیکی ذرائع میں پیش کیا گیا ہے ، "گمراہ" کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں جنہوں نے نبی of کے صحیح جانشینوں کو ترک کردیا ، جس کی وجہ سے بچائے گئے گروہوں سے ابدی علیحدگی اختیار کی گئی۔ فقہی طور پر ، یہ شیعہ کے نظریہ کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے کہ اماموں پر عمل پیرا ہونا محض ایک نظریاتی ترجیح نہیں ہے بلکہ عقیدے کا بنیادی ستون ہے ، جس میں اسکیوٹولوجیکل نتائج ہیں۔ اس طرح یہ آیت الہی سچائی ، پیشن گوئی کی میراث ، اور اہل بائٹ سے بیعت کی ضرورت کے مابین لازم و ملزوم روابط کی ایک یاد دہانی کا کام کرتی ہے۔
51.layer3_urdu:
عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ الواقیہ 56:51 کو اکثر فکری اور روحانی جمود کے خلاف گہری انتباہ کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے *طافسیر نمونیہ *میں ، اس بات پر زور دیا ہے کہ یہاں حوالہ دیا گیا "انکار" (مکدیبون) محض ملحد نہیں بلکہ سچائی تک رسائی کے باوجود خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔ آج اخلاقی ، ماحولیاتی ، یا معاشرتی ذمہ داریوں کی جان بوجھ کر لاعلمی شامل کرنے کے لئے ایک تصور میں توسیع کی گئی ہے۔ ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے جدید اسکالرز اس "گمراہی" (ڈیلون) ریاست کو ایسے نظاموں سے جوڑتے ہیں جو انسانی وقار پر مادیت کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جیسے استحصالی سرمایہ داری یا آمرانہ حکومتیں جو اختلاف کو دباتی ہیں۔  

سائنسی بصیرت اس تنقید کو بڑھاوا دیتی ہے: آب و ہوا کی تبدیلی سے انکار ، بہت زیادہ شواہد کے باوجود ، آیت کی سہولت کے لئے حقیقت کو مسترد کرنے کی مذمت کا آئینہ دار ہے۔ فلسفی ڈاکٹر لیاکات تکیم نے قرآنی "انکار" اور جدید رشتہ داری کے مابین متوازی نوٹ کیا جو معروضی اخلاقیات کو مسترد کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ استدلال کرتے ہیں کہ دونوں ظلم اور عدم مساوات کو قابل بناتے ہیں۔ اس آیت کی عجلت میں ویکسین ہچکچاہٹ جیسے ویکسین ہچکچاہٹ یا غلط معلومات کی مہمات جیسے معاشرتی ہم آہنگی کو فریکچر دیتے ہیں۔  

بین المذاہب مکالمے ، خاص طور پر عیسائی آزادی کے الہیات اور بدھ مت کے ذہن سازی کی اخلاقیات کے ساتھ ، اجتماعی احتساب کے ذریعہ اس "بھٹکے" کا مقابلہ کرنے میں مشترکہ بنیاد تلاش کرتے ہیں۔ اس آیت نے کثیر الثقافتی معاشروں کو چیلنج کیا ہے کہ وہ اسلامو فوبیا سے مہاجرین کے بحرانوں تک نظامی ناانصافیوں کو دور کریں۔  

آخر کار ، یہ آیت سچائی کے ساتھ فعال مشغولیت کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے ، اور برادریوں سے سائنسی پیشرفت ، معاشرتی انصاف اور روحانی سالمیت کو سیدھ میں لانے کی تاکید کرتی ہے۔ جیسا کہ اسکالر ڈاکٹر ماریہ ڈاکیک نے مشاہدہ کیا ہے ، یہ ایک "طوادک شعور" کی دعوت دیتا ہے جہاں الہی اتحاد کو تسلیم کرنے سے جدید جھوٹ کا مقابلہ کرنے کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔
51.layer4_urdu:
سورہ الواقیا کی گہری گہرائیوں میں ، آیت 51 میں ان لوگوں سے خطاب کیا گیا ہے جو الہی سچائی سے بھٹک رہے ہیں جبکہ تکبر سے اس کی تردید کرتے ہیں۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن) یہ سکھاتے ہیں کہ روحانی "گمراہی" (ایلل) کی جڑیں اماموں کے ولیہ (سرپرستی) میں مجسم الہی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرنے میں ہیں۔ امام جافر السادق (اس پر امن ہے) نے کہا ہے ، * "'' انکار '' وہ لوگ ہیں جو ان کے جاننے کے بعد اہل بیت کے حقوق کو مسترد کرتے ہیں their ان کے دلوں کو ان کے اپنے جبر سے مہر لگا دیا گیا ہے" * (طافسیر القومی)۔ اس طرح یہ آیت دانشورانہ تکبر کے خلاف متنبہ کرتی ہے جو اماموں کے برائٹ راہ کو مسترد کرتی ہے ، جو زندہ قرآنی ترجمان ہیں۔  

لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن ہے) اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں اس کو روشن کرتی ہے: * "جو بھی اللہ کی رسی کو برقرار نہیں رکھتا ہے وہ بدعنوانی میں پھسل جائے گا" * (بہار الانور)۔ یہاں "رسی" قرآنی سچائی اور الہی مقرر کردہ اماموں کے مابین لازم و ملزوم روابط کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے۔ ان کے اختیار سے انکار کرنا - خاص طور پر یا سیاسی طور پر - "انکار کرنے والوں" میں سے ایک کو بہتر بناتا ہے ، چاہے ظاہری طور پر متقی ہو۔  

روحانی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو خود سے عکاسی کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے: کیا ہم امامہ کو ایمان کے محور کے طور پر ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، یا کیا ہم دنیاوی تعصبات کو اپنی پیش کش کو بادل دیتے ہیں؟ امام علی (اس پر سلامتی) سکھاتا ہے کہ * "سب سے بڑی گمراہی آپ کے وقت کے امام کی مخالفت کرنا ہے" * (ناہج البالاگھا)۔ عملی طور پر ، اس کا مطالبہ ہے کہ وہ زندہ امام کی تعلیمات کے ساتھ کسی کے دل اور افعال کو سیدھ میں رکھیں ، دعا الہد جیسی التجا کے ذریعہ اس کی رہنمائی حاصل کریں اور اس کے مقصد سے وفاداری کی پرورش کریں۔  

"ان لوگوں کو گمراہ کرنے" سے بچنے کے ل one ، کسی کو اہل بیت کے قرآنی استثنیٰ میں غرق کرنا چاہئے ، انصاف کو اپنی طرح برقرار رکھنا چاہئے ، اور روزانہ ارادوں کو پاک کرنا چاہئے۔ جیسا کہ امام البقیر (اس پر سلامتی ہے) نے کہا ، "ہمارا ولیہ اللہ کا ویلیح ہے۔ کسی کو بھی پاکیزہ کے سوا کوئی نہیں حاصل ہوتا ہے" * (الکافی)۔ اس آیت کو ہمیں ان کی روشنی سے چمٹے رہنے کے لئے بیدار ہونے دیں ، کہیں ایسا نہ ہو کہ ان کی نجات کو ختم کردیں۔
51.layer5:
In examining Surah 56:51, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core eschatological context, identifying the “astray deniers” as those rejecting resurrection and divine accountability. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) align in interpreting this as a rebuke to pre-Islamic Arab skeptics, with Al-Tabari emphasizing their categorical denial of the afterlife (Jami al-Bayan) and Al-Tusi (At-Tibyan) noting their moral deviation from prophetic warnings. The Qurtubi (Al-Jami li-Ahkam) and Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) similarly stress the link between theological denial and ethical corruption, reflecting shared ethical concerns across traditions.

Divergences emerge in historical contextualization and implied referents. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir (Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim) generally frame the “astray” as generic rejecters, while Shia sources like Al-Qummi (Tafsir al-Qummi) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) often read the verse through post-prophetic leadership disputes. Al-Qummi alludes to those who “denied the truth after knowing it”—a phrase Shia scholars historically apply to opponents of Imam Ali’s authority. This reflects the Shia theological principle of linking spiritual guidance to the Ahl al-Bayt, whereas Sunni exegesis typically avoids such specific political applications.

Theological foundations further differ: Al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) analyzes the verse’s rhetorical structure as a universal warning against intellectual arrogance, while Tabatabai philosophically ties “astray” to neglecting the Imam’s ontological role as humanity’s spiritual axis (Al-Mizan). These distinctions subtly influence religious practice, with Shia spirituality emphasizing allegiance to the Imams as safeguards against deviation, whereas Sunni interpretations prioritize correct belief and communal adherence to Quranic norms.

Historically, these differences stem from distinct approaches to Quranic hermeneutics. Sunni tafsir often prioritizes the text’s apparent meaning (zahir) and early community consensus, while Shia scholarship frequently incorporates the hidden (batin) dimensions believed to be elucidated by the Imams. Both traditions, however, maintain the verse’s central ethical imperative: rejecting truth claims bears grave existential consequences.

In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:51), Allah addresses two groups with striking clarity: *al-dalloon* (those astray) and *al-mukaththiboon* (the deniers). This verse forms part of a vivid depiction of the Day of Judgment, where three groups are distinguished: the foremost believers, the companions of the right, and these "astray deniers. " The phrase *thumma innakum* ("Then indeed you") carries a weight of inevitability, emphasizing that after the clear signs and warnings, accountability becomes unavoidable. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, *"The 'deniers' are those who reject the rights of the Ahlul Bayt after knowing them; their hearts are sealed by their own oppression"* (Tafsir al-Qummi). This verse invites self-reflection: Are we dismissing truths—spiritual, ethical, or social—out of convenience or pride? In an age where materialism and moral relativism challenge faith, *al-dalloon* and *al-mukaththiboon* manifest as those who deny accountability to Allah, reject the necessity of justice, or ignore the rights of others taught by the Quran and Ahlul Bayt.
51.layer2short: In Surah al-Waaqia (56:51), the verse “Then indeed you, O those astray [who are] deniers” addresses those who persistently reject divine truth after its manifestation. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, contextualize this verse within the broader eschatological framework of the surah, which categorizes humanity into three groups on the Day of Judgment: the *sabiqun* (foremost in faith), the *ashab al-yamin* (companions of the right), and the *mukadhibun* (deniers). The verse directly rebukes the third group, identified as those who deviated from divine guidance and rejected prophetic teachings, including the Wilayah (divinely ordained authority) of the Ahlul Bayt.

52.layer1:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:52), Allah describes the fate of those who reject truth and justice, stating they "will be eating from trees of zaqqum." This verse forms part of a vivid depiction of the Day of Judgment, where the "companions of the left" (those who opposed divine guidance) face punishment. The term *zaqqum* refers to a cursed tree in Hell, described in other verses (e.g., 37:62-68) as bearing poisonous, scalding fruits resembling the heads of devils. Its name derives from the root *z-q-m*, conjoining ideas of bitterness and suffocation, symbolizing the spiritual and physical torment awaiting oppressors.  

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasises that *zaqqum* represents the ultimate consequence of persistent arrogance and moral corruption. Historically, this Meccan surah confronted the Quraysh’s denial of resurrection, using stark imagery to affirm divine justice. The verse contrasts the lush, blessed trees of Paradise with the *shajar* (tree) of *zaqqum*, illustrating how evil deeds transform divine blessings into instruments of punishment.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse serves as a timeless warning against complacency in faith and ethical conduct. It urges self-reflection: Are our actions nourishing our souls or poisoning them? The *zaqqum* metaphorically represents modern vices—greed, oppression, or heedlessness—that "choke" spiritual growth. Practically, it calls Muslims to align their lives with Quranic values, reject injustice, and cultivate gratitude for Allah’s blessings. By internalising this imagery, believers can resist temptations that lead to spiritual ruin, striving instead for the "fruits" of righteousness that promise eternal peace.
52.layer2:
In Surah al-Waaqia (56:52), the verse’s reference to the “tree of Zaqqum” as sustenance for the damned in Hell invokes profound theological and moral symbolism within classical Shia exegesis. The Zaqqum, described elsewhere in the Quran (e.g., 37:62-68) as a repulsive tree with fruits resembling devils’ heads, is interpreted by Shia scholars as both a literal manifestation of divine punishment and a metaphor for the spiritual corruption of those who reject truth. As Tabrisi elucidates in *Majma al-Bayan*, the tree epitomizes the inversion of divine mercy: while the righteous are granted paradisiacal fruits, the unjust are condemned to consume the bitter consequences of their moral choices. This duality underscores the Shia principle of *‘adl* (divine justice), wherein punishment corresponds precisely to one’s deeds, reflecting God’s absolute fairness.

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands on this by framing the Zaqqum as a symbol of self-destructive arrogance. Drawing from narrations attributed to Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, he notes that the tree’s “boiling fluid” (56:54) represents the internalization of worldly greed and oppression, which transmutes into spiritual agony in the hereafter. The imagery thus serves as a stark reminder of the *akhirah*’s ontological reality, where abstract sins materialize as tangible suffering. Shia commentators also link this verse to the rejection of *wilayah* (allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt), as the denial of divinely appointed guidance is seen as a root cause of such damnation. The Zaqqum’s repulsiveness, therefore, mirrors the moral degradation of those who oppose truth, a theme recurrent in Shia eschatology. 

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the ethical imperative to avoid *kufr* (disbelief) and *zulm* (oppression), aligning actions with the Quranic worldview. Its placement in Surah al-Waaqia—a chapter emphasizing resurrection and accountability—highlights the inseparable Shia nexus between doctrine, ethics, and eschatology, urging adherence to the path of the Ahl al-Bayt as salvation from such fates.
52.layer3:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:52), the mention of *zaqqum*—a thorny, bitter tree in Hell—has long intrigued scholars. Contemporary Shia thinkers like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi and Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali reframe this imagery beyond literal punishment, viewing it as a metaphor for self-destructive choices rooted in greed, injustice, or moral decay. Shirazi notes in *Tafsir Nemuneh* that zaqqum symbolises the "bitter fruits" of systemic oppression or ecological exploitation, where societies "consume" harm through unethical practices.  

Scientifically, parallels emerge with environmental crises: zaqqum’s description as a toxic, inedible plant mirrors modern realities of deforestation, pollution, or monoculture farming that degrade ecosystems. Philosopher Dr. Fatemah Meghji connects this to *tawhid* (divine unity), arguing that zaqqum represents humanity’s rupture with nature’s balance—a theme echoed in Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’*, bridging Islamic and Christian eco-theology.  

Socially, the verse critiques consumerism and inequity. Scholar Sayed Ammar Nakshawani links zaqqum to "spiritual malnutrition" in hyper-capitalist societies, where material excess breeds existential emptiness. This resonates with global issues like food waste amid famine or addiction to unsustainable technologies.  

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here: Buddhist concepts of *dukkha* (suffering from desire) and Hindu *karma* align with zaqqum’s symbolism of cause-effect in moral choices. Multiculturally, the verse urges collective responsibility—whether addressing climate change or ethical AI—by framing zaqqum as a warning against prioritising short-term gain over holistic wellbeing.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modernity to recognise that "eating from zaqqum" isn’t merely otherworldly; it manifests wherever humanity severs ethics from progress.
52.layer4:
The verse describing the punishment of eating from the tree of Zaqqum (56:52) is illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (as) as a profound spiritual metaphor. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) taught that zaqqum represents the bitter fruits of rejecting divine guidance, explaining: "The tree of Zaqqum is the tree whose roots are in the hearts of those who denied the Wilayah of Ali ibn Abi Talib (as), and its branches are their evil deeds rising up to choke them." This interpretation connects the physical description of Hell's punishment to the spiritual consequences of opposing the Imamah.

Lady Fatimah (as) warned in her historic sermon: "Beware of the fire whose fuel is men and stones - its sparks are the doubts you nurture against the chosen ones of Allah." The zaqqum's poison symbolizes the self-inflicted torment of doubting or rejecting the divinely appointed guides. Conversely, the nourishment of Paradise is understood by Shia tradition as the sweetness of recognizing and adhering to the Wilayah of the Imams.

Imam Ali (as) taught that "The zaqqum of this world is the unlawful morsel swallowed by a hungry soul - its fire burns long before the Hereafter." This transforms the verse into practical guidance: every choice to indulge in forbidden acts or neglect obligatory duties plants seeds of this cursed tree within the soul. The remedy lies in constant remembrance of the Imams' teachings and seeking nourishment through permissible deeds aligned with their guidance.

To avoid the zaqqum's fate, believers are advised to recite the Ziyarat of the Imams regularly, purify their intentions through sincere repentance, and consciously align their actions with the ethical framework taught by the Ahlul Bayt. As Imam al-Baqir (as) said: "The fire of zaqqum is extinguished by the water of love for us - love that flows through obedience and tears of remorse." This spiritual approach transforms the verse from mere warning to a roadmap for salvation through conscious submission to divine authority as manifested in the Imamah.

52.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Waaqia 56:52, both Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge on the literal understanding of zaqqum as a repulsive tree in Hell, described by Al-Tabari (Sunni) as "a nourishment of punishment" causing agony through its bitterness and heat. This aligns with Shia sources like Al-Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, which emphasizes its physical torment as divine retribution for disbelievers. Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Al-Qummi (Shia) both cite prophetic hadiths describing zaqqum’s revolting appearance, reflecting shared eschatological imagery rooted in the Quran’s vivid warnings.

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi often contextualize zaqqum within broader discussions of Allah’s justice (*adl*) and the necessity of literal Hellfire for unrepentant sinners. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Tababatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Al-Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) incorporate metaphysical dimensions, interpreting zaqqum as symbolic of the spiritual consequences of rejecting divine guidance—particularly the wilaya (guardianship) of the Ahlul Bayt. Al-Qummi’s narration from Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq links zaqqum to the "fruit of oppression," alluding to historical injustices against the Prophet’s household, a theme less prominent in Sunni works.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes textual literalism and God’s omnipotence, while Shia tafsir integrates Imamah theology and the socio-political legacy of early Islam. Both traditions, however, reinforce the verse’s core ethical imperative: deterring moral transgression through eschatological accountability. Practically, this shared focus sustains devotional practices emphasizing repentance and ethical vigilance across Muslim communities, while divergent symbolic interpretations reflect historical developments in sect-specific theological priorities.

52.layer2short: In Surah al-Waaqia (56:52), the verse’s reference to the “tree of Zaqqum” as sustenance for the damned in Hell invokes profound theological and moral symbolism within classical Shia exegesis. The Zaqqum, described elsewhere in the Quran (e.g., 37:62-68) as a repulsive tree with fruits resembling devils’ heads, is interpreted by Shia scholars as both a literal manifestation of divine punishment and a metaphor for the spiritual corruption of those who reject truth. As Tabrisi elucidates in *Majma al-Bayan*, the tree epitomizes the inversion of divine mercy: while the righteous are granted paradisiacal fruits, the unjust are condemned to consume the bitter consequences of their moral choices. This duality underscores the Shia principle of *‘adl* (divine justice), wherein punishment corresponds precisely to one’s deeds, reflecting God’s absolute fairness.

53.layer1:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:53), the phrase *فَمَالِـُٔونَ مِنْهَا ٱلْبُطُونَ* ("And filling with it your bellies") forms part of a vivid depiction of the punishment awaiting the *ashab al-shimal* (companions of the left) in the Hereafter. This verse follows descriptions of the cursed tree *Zaqqum* (verse 52), whose bitter fruit becomes the sustenance of those who rejected truth and justice. The verb *مالئون* (filling) derives from the root *م ل ء*, conveying completion or saturation, while *البطون* (bellies) emphasizes physical consumption. Here, the act of eating—ordinarily a source of nourishment—becomes a metaphor for divine retribution, as the disbelievers’ *batn* (stomach) is painfully filled with the consequences of their spiritual choices.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, contextualizes this verse within the Quran’s broader eschatological themes. Revealed in Mecca during intense persecution of early Muslims, Surah Al-Waaqia reassured the faithful while warning oppressors of accountability. The *Zaqqum* symbolizes the inversion of worldly power: those who indulged in arrogance or exploited others will face a "fullness" devoid of satisfaction, contrasting with the *ashab al-yamin* (companions of the right), who enjoy heavenly blessings. Imam Ali, in *Nahj al-Balagha*, often linked physical consumption to spiritual states, teaching that indulgence in haram sustenance corrupts the soul.

For modern Muslims, this verse invites reflection on ethical consumption and intentionality. Beyond literal food, it critiques greed, exploitation, and attachment to transient pleasures. In a world of excess and inequality, filling one’s "belly" can represent hoarding wealth, consuming unethical products, or neglecting social responsibility. Shia ethics, rooted in the Imams’ teachings, urge believers to seek *halal* sustenance, practice moderation, and prioritize spiritual "nourishment" through acts like charity (*zakat*) and remembrance of Allah (*dhikr*). The verse ultimately reminds us that our choices—both material and moral—shape our eternal destiny, urging alignment with divine justice in daily life.
53.layer2:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:53), the phrase "filling with it your bellies" forms part of a vivid eschatological depiction addressing the fate of the "companions of the left" (ashab al-mashama). Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the hermeneutical traditions of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret this verse as describing the punishment of those who rejected divine guidance, compelled to consume the bitter fruit of the *Zaqqum* tree in the hereafter. Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasises the literal reality of this torment, noting that the verse underscores the principle of *maswiyya* (correspondence between deeds and recompense): just as these individuals "filled their bellies" with forbidden (haram) sustenance in worldly life, they are now forced to ingest the physical manifestation of their spiritual corruption.

Imam Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* expands this into a metaphysical analysis, arguing that the "filling" denotes the internalisation of one’s moral choices. The verse symbolises how the soul becomes saturated with the consequences of its actions, rendering the punishment both a divine decree and a self-created reality. This aligns with the Shia theological concept of *kash* (acquisition), wherein humans bear responsibility for shaping their eternal states through volitional acts. 

The imagery also carries juridical implications. Classical scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi link this verse to the prohibition of consuming illicit wealth (mal al-haram), as it spiritually prepares the soul for such eschatological retribution. Furthermore, traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq contextualise the verse within the framework of *walaya* (allegiance to the Imams), teaching that rejection of the Ahlul Bayt’s guidance leads to spiritual starvation masked by physical satiety. Thus, the verse transcends mere physical description, serving as a nexus between ontology, ethics, and the Shia doctrine of divinely ordained justice (adl)
53.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Waaqia 56:53 — “And filling with it your bellies” — is often interpreted through lenses of ecological ethics, social justice, and spiritual mindfulness. While classical commentaries link this verse to the *zaqqum* tree’s symbolic punishment for those who rejected divine truth, modern thinkers like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasise its relevance to humanity’s exploitative relationship with natural resources. He notes that the verse’s imagery of “filling bellies” critiques unchecked consumption, urging believers to reflect on overconsumption’s ethical and environmental costs.  

Scientific insights amplify this message: studies on food waste (1.3 billion tonnes annually, per UNEP) and climate-linked agricultural crises mirror the Quranic warning against excess. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to *tawhid* (divine unity), arguing that ecological imbalance disrupts creation’s harmony — a theological parallel to industrial overexploitation. Socially, the verse resonates with global inequities: while 800 million face hunger, others obsess over luxury diets. The Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on *qana’a* (contentment) and sharing resources, as highlighted by Ayatollah Sayyid Fadlallah, frame this as a call to address systemic greed and food apartheid.  

Interfaith dialogues draw parallels: Buddhist “right livelihood,” Christian stewardship ethics, and Indigenous sustainability practices all echo the Quran’s caution against excess. Multiculturally, the verse challenges consumerist ideologies that prioritise profit over planetary health, urging collective responsibility. In an era of climate collapse and widening inequality, this verse becomes a manifesto for balance — spiritually, ecologically, and socially — aligning divine wisdom with modern imperatives for survival.
53.layer4:
In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), the verse "And filling with it your bellies" (56:53) transcends its apparent meaning of physical sustenance, unveiling profound truths about spiritual nourishment and the consequences of attachment to worldly desires. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "The 'bellies' here symbolize the soul’s capacity to be filled either with the fire of heedlessness or the light of divine recognition. Those who feed their inner selves with love for the Ahlul Bayt will be satiated with the fruits of Paradise, while those consumed by worldly cravings shall taste the thorns of regret."

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that true satiation lies in aligning one’s heart with the remembrance of Allah and the Wilayah of the Imams. She said, "The believer’s belly is never filled except by the sustenance of obedience [to Allah] and the hunger for His nearness." This echoes the Shia understanding that physical acts like eating carry spiritual weight; moderation in consumption becomes a means to purify the soul and strengthen one’s connection to the Divine.

Imam Ali (peace be upon him) warns in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Beware lest your stomachs become graves for forbidden pleasures." Here, the "filling of bellies" serves as a metaphor for indulging in materialism, which blinds the heart to the eternal truths upheld by the Imamah. The verse thus calls believers to seek nourishment through the spiritual guidance of the Imams—the true "food" for the soul—by engaging in acts that cultivate inner awareness: reciting the Qur’an, reflecting on the tragedies of Karbala, and performing nightly prayers. 

Practically, this verse invites self-examination: What are we feeding our souls daily? Let every morsel we consume remind us to hunger for the presence of the Ahlul Bayt, whose teachings are the eternal cure for spiritual starvation.

53.layer5:
The verse “فَمَالِـُٔونَ مِنْهَا ٱلْبُطُونَ” (“And filling with it your bellies”) forms part of a vivid depiction of the punishment awaiting disbelievers in the afterlife. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur on the verse’s eschatological context, interpreting it as a reference to the torment of consuming the accursed tree of *Zaqqum* (mentioned in 56:52), which fills the stomachs of the damned with agonizing heat. Scholars like Shia’s Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) and Sunni’s Ibn Kathir (*Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim*) emphasize the literal reality of this punishment, rooted in the Quran’s graphic imagery of divine justice. Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam al-Quran*) similarly highlight its symbolic resonance, underscoring the principle that human actions yield commensurate consequences in the hereafter.  

Divergences emerge in theological nuance. Shia commentaries, such as Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi*, often link the verse to the moral and spiritual corruption of rejecting divine guidance, particularly the *wilayah* (guardianship) of the Ahlul Bayt. This aligns with Shia emphasis on the Imam’s role as the spiritual and interpretive authority. Sunni scholars like Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) and Tabari (*Jami al-Bayan*) focus more on the ontological nature of the punishment, debating whether the “filling” denotes physical suffering or a metaphorical expression of inescapable regret.  

These distinctions reflect broader hermeneutical frameworks: Shia tafsir frequently integrates the teachings of the Imams as a lens for moral and allegorical interpretation, while Sunni traditions prioritize textual and rational analysis grounded in the Prophet’s Sunnah and companion narratives. Historically, these approaches stem from differing theological priorities—Shia emphasis on the Imam’s authority versus Sunni focus on communal consensus (*ijma*) and transmitted tradition (*naql*).  

Both traditions, however, unite in using this verse to reinforce the Quranic warning against disbelief, urging believers toward spiritual vigilance. The interpretations, while distinct in emphasis, collectively affirm the Quran’s central message of accountability and divine justice.

یہ امتیازات وسیع تر ہرمینیٹیکل فریم ورک کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں: شیعہ طافسر بار بار اخلاقی اور نظریاتی تشریح کے عینک کے طور پر اماموں کی تعلیمات کو مربوط کرتا ہے ، جبکہ سنی روایات نبی کی سنت اور ساتھی کی داستانوں میں مبنی متنی اور عقلی تجزیہ کو ترجیح دیتی ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ نقطہ نظر مختلف مذہبی ترجیحات سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں۔  

تاہم ، دونوں روایات کفر کے خلاف قرآنی انتباہ کو تقویت دینے کے لئے اس آیت کو استعمال کرنے میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں ، اور مومنین کو روحانی چوکسی پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ تشریحات ، جبکہ زور سے الگ ہیں ، اجتماعی طور پر قرآن مجید کے احتساب اور خدائی انصاف کے مرکزی پیغام کی تصدیق کرتے ہیں۔

53.layer2short: In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:53), the phrase "filling with it your bellies" forms part of a vivid eschatological depiction addressing the fate of the "companions of the left" (ashab al-mashama). Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the hermeneutical traditions of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret this verse as describing the punishment of those who rejected divine guidance, compelled to consume the bitter fruit of the *Zaqqum* tree in the hereafter. Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasises the literal reality of this torment, noting that the verse underscores the principle of *maswiyya* (correspondence between deeds and recompense): just as these individuals "filled their bellies" with forbidden (haram) sustenance in worldly life, they are now forced to ingest the physical manifestation of their spiritual corruption.

54.layer1:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:54), Allah describes a grim scene of divine punishment: "Then drinking on top of it from scalding water [al-hamim]." This verse forms part of a broader depiction of the Hellfire’s torments reserved for those who rejected truth and lived in arrogance. The phrase "sharibuna alayhi" (drinking on top of it) indicates a layered punishment: after consuming the bitter tree of Zaqqum (mentioned in the preceding verse), the damned are forced to gulp boiling liquid that intensifies their agony. The term al-hamim refers not merely to hot water but to a corrosive, superheated substance that scalds internally and externally, symbolizing the inescapable consequences of spiritual corruption.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this imagery underscores the principle of divine justice: actions in this life generate their own spiritual "substances" that manifest in the hereafter. The verse, revealed during the Meccan period, confronted the Quraysh’s materialism and denial of resurrection, urging them to recognize the moral weight of their choices. The word al-hamim itself derives from the root ḥ-m-m, connoting intense heat and suffocation—a visceral metaphor for the spiritual "burn" of wasted potential and hardened hearts.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse serves as a timeless reminder to cultivate self-awareness and accountability. Just as physical toxins harm the body, moral negligence—like greed, dishonesty, or neglect of the vulnerable—poisons the soul. In Shia thought, this connects to the Imam Ali’s teachings on nurturing taqwa (God-consciousness) and social justice: avoiding the "scalding" consequences of sin requires actively quenching societal and spiritual thirsts through charity, ethical conduct, and remembrance of the Ahlul Bayt’s guidance. It calls believers to reflect: what "heat" am I generating through my choices, and how can I replace it with the coolness of faith?
54.layer2:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:54), the phrase "drinking on top of it from scalding water" forms part of the Quran’s vivid depiction of the punishment awaiting those who reject divine truth. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, interpret this verse as a continuation of the torments described in the preceding verses, where the damned are compelled to consume the bitter fruit of Zaqqum (56:52–53), followed by boiling water that exacerbates their suffering. Tabrisi notes the compounding nature of this punishment, emphasising that the scalding water (*al-hamim*) is imbibed immediately after ingesting the accursed tree, symbolising a layered retribution for persistent disbelief and moral corruption.

Tabatabai elucidates that such imagery underscores the principle of *muqafat al-amal* (requital commensurate with deeds), a cornerstone of Shia theology rooted in divine justice (*‘adl*). The "scalding" nature of the drink reflects the spiritual burning caused by the rejection of truth and the abandonment of the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, whose wilayah (spiritual authority) is integral to salvation. This punishment, while physical in description, embodies the metaphysical consequences of a soul’s alienation from its divine purpose.

The verse also resonates with Shia eschatology, which views the afterlife as a mirror of one’s earthly choices. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, links such Quranic descriptions to the state of souls burdened by unrepentant sin and denial of the Imamate. Jurisprudentially, this serves as a dire reminder of the necessity to align actions with the ethical and legal framework established by the Ahlul Bayt, whose teachings alone illuminate the path to spiritual safety. Thus, the verse transcends mere physical warning, urging profound introspection on the soul’s trajectory in light of divine accountability.
54.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Waaqia’s vivid imagery of sinners “drinking scalding water” (56:54) is interpreted through layered ethical, ecological, and existential lenses. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, notes that the verse symbolises the self-destructive consequences of moral corruption—where the “scalding” torment reflects the spiritual burn of guilt and alienation from divine purpose. This aligns with modern psychological insights into the anguish of living without ethical grounding, a theme echoed by scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, who links Quranic metaphors to the existential crises of modernity, such as nihilism or consumerist excess.

Ecologically, scholars such as Sayyid Rizwan Arastu draw parallels between the “scalding” punishment and humanity’s reckless exploitation of natural resources. The verse’s imagery resonates with climate crises—boiling oceans, wildfires, and water scarcity—framed as both physical and metaphysical consequences of ecological injustice. This interpretation invites reflection on Quranic warnings as prescient critiques of unsustainable practices, urging stewardship aligned with the *khalifa* (trusteeship) principle.

Socially, the verse’s duality of thirst and scalding speaks to contemporary inequities: billions lack clean water while others overconsume, mirroring the Quranic paradox of unquenchable yet torturous desire. Philosopher Dr. Shabbir Akhtar highlights this in interfaith dialogues, comparing it to Buddhist teachings on craving (*tanha*) and Christian notions of spiritual drought. Such cross-cultural resonance underscores shared ethical imperatives amid global challenges—from climate collapse to economic disparity—positioning the verse as a timeless call for balance, justice, and mindful living.
54.layer4:
The verse "And drinking on top of it from scalding water" (56:54) is illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as) as a profound metaphor for the spiritual consequences of rejecting divine truth. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explains that the "scalding water" symbolizes the burning regret and spiritual agony experienced by those who prioritized worldly desires over the recognition of Allah’s chosen guides. In *Tafsir al-Qummi*, it is narrated that the Imams taught this punishment represents the "heat of wasted opportunities" — the torment of realizing one’s failure to drink from the fountain of guidance offered by the Ahlul Bayt (as) in this life.  

Lady Fatimah (as) emphasized in her famed sermon, "The scalding of the soul is fiercer than the scalding of fire," highlighting that neglecting the *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) of the Imams creates an inner void that cannot be quenched. The "scalding water" thus becomes the antithesis of the "pure drink" (76:21) promised to the righteous — a drink drawn from the spiritual river of Muhammad (s) and his purified progeny.  

Imam Ali (as) warns in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The thirst of the heart is not quenched except by the water of divine love." Practically, this verse urges believers to seek the "coolness of certainty" by anchoring their hearts to the Imams’ teachings. Each act of disobedience is a sip from the "scalding water" of heedlessness, while adherence to the Ahlul Bayt (as) transforms one’s spiritual palate to crave the sweetness of truth.  

To avoid this fate, the Imams taught daily reflection on one’s connection to the *Imamah*, seeking forgiveness through their intercession, and nurturing the soul with acts that affirm divine guardianship. As Imam al-Baqir (as) said: "The fire of this verse is extinguished by the tears of those who weep for Hussain (as)," linking devotion to the Ahlul Bayt (as) to salvation from all forms of spiritual burning.

ماحولیاتی طور پر ، سید رضوان ارسو جیسے اسکالرز "اسکیلڈنگ" سزا اور انسانیت کے قدرتی وسائل کے لاپرواہی استحصال کے مابین متوازی کھینچتے ہیں۔ آیت کی منظر کشی آب و ہوا کے بحرانوں کے ساتھ گونجتی ہے - بحر اوقیانوس ، جنگل کی آگ ، اور پانی کی قلت - ماحولیاتی ناانصافی کے جسمانی اور استعاریاتی نتائج دونوں کے طور پر تیار کی گئی ہے۔ یہ تشریح قرآنی انتباہات پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے کیونکہ غیر مستحکم طریقوں کے قدیم نقادوں کے طور پر ، * خلیفہ * (ٹرسٹ شپ) اصول کے ساتھ منسلک اسٹیورشپ پر زور دیا گیا ہے۔

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت کی پیاس اور اسکیلڈنگ کی دوہری ہم عصر عدم مساوات پر بات کرتی ہے: اربوں افراد میں صاف پانی کی کمی ہے جبکہ دوسروں کو زیادہ حد سے تجاوز کرتے ہوئے ، ناقابل تلافی لیکن اذیت ناک خواہش کے قرآنی تضاد کا آئینہ دار ہے۔ فلسفی ڈاکٹر شبیر اختر نے بین المذاہب مکالموں میں اس پر روشنی ڈالی ، اس کا موازنہ بدھ مت کی تعلیمات (*تنہ*) اور روحانی خشک سالی کے مسیحی تصورات سے کیا۔ اس طرح کی ثقافتی گونج عالمی چیلنجوں کے درمیان مشترکہ اخلاقی عدم استحکام کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے-آب و ہوا کے خاتمے سے لے کر معاشی تفاوت تک-اس آیت کو توازن ، انصاف اور ذہن سازی کی زندگی کے لئے ایک لازوال کال کے طور پر قرار دیتے ہیں۔
54.layer4_urdu:

امام علی (ع) نے *ناہج البالاگھا *میں متنبہ کیا ہے: "دل کی پیاس کو الہی محبت کے پانی کے سوا نہیں بجھایا جاتا ہے۔" عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو اماموں کی تعلیمات پر اپنے دلوں کو لنگر انداز کرکے "یقین کی ٹھنڈک" کی تلاش کرنے کی تاکید کرتی ہے۔ نافرمانی کا ہر عمل غفلت کے "اسکیلڈنگ واٹر" کا گھونٹ ہوتا ہے ، جبکہ احلول بیت (ع) کی پاسداری کسی کے روحانی تالے کو سچائی کی مٹھاس کو ترسنے کے ل. تبدیل کرتی ہے۔

54.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Waaqia 56:54, both Shia and Sunni scholars converge on the verse’s core eschatological meaning: a vivid depiction of divine punishment for disbelievers in the afterlife. Classical exegetes across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia), emphasize the literal description of *hamim* (scalding water) as a torment following consumption of the cursed tree *Zaqqum* (mentioned in 56:52), underscoring the Quran’s thematic linkage between moral corruption and physical suffering. Ibn Kathir and Al-Mizan’s Tabatabai both contextualize this within broader Quranic warnings about resurrection and accountability, reflecting shared theological foundations in divine justice.

Divergences emerge in hermeneutical approaches. Shia commentaries like Tusi’s At-Tibyan and Qummi’s Tafsir often incorporate traditions from the Ahlul Bayt to highlight symbolic dimensions, interpreting *hamim* as emblematic of spiritual deprivation resulting from rejecting divine guidance. Tabatabai further ties this to the necessity of Imamah (divinely appointed leadership) for salvation, a perspective absent in Sunni works. Conversely, Sunni scholars such as Qurtubi and Razi prioritize philological analysis and historical context, with Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb exploring the physiological plausibility of the punishment as a sign of God’s creative power.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Shia exegesis frequently integrates Imamah into cosmic justice, while Sunni tafsir traditionally focuses on God’s omnipotence and textual clarity. Practically, Shia interpretations may reinforce devotion to the Ahlul Bayt as spiritual protectors, whereas Sunni readings often emphasize individual responsibility. Historically, these trajectories reflect early Islamic debates over authority and scriptural interpretation, with Shia scholars privileging transmitted teachings of the Imams and Sunni exegetes consolidating around consensus (*ijma*) and textual literalism. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s moral imperative: heedfulness of divine reckoning.

In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:54), Allah describes a grim scene of divine punishment: "Then drinking on top of it from scalding water [al-hamim]. " This verse forms part of a broader depiction of the Hellfire’s torments reserved for those who rejected truth and lived in arrogance. The phrase "sharibuna alayhi" (drinking on top of it) indicates a layered punishment: after consuming the bitter tree of Zaqqum (mentioned in the preceding verse), the damned are forced to gulp boiling liquid that intensifies their agony. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explains that the "scalding water" symbolizes the burning regret and spiritual agony experienced by those who prioritized worldly desires over the recognition of Allah’s chosen guides. In Shia thought, this connects to the Imam Ali’s teachings on nurturing taqwa (God-consciousness) and social justice: avoiding the "scalding" consequences of sin requires actively quenching societal and spiritual thirsts through charity, ethical conduct, and remembrance of the Ahlul Bayt’s guidance.
54.layer2short: In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:54), the phrase "drinking on top of it from scalding water" forms part of the Quran’s vivid depiction of the punishment awaiting those who reject divine truth. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, interpret this verse as a continuation of the torments described in the preceding verses, where the damned are compelled to consume the bitter fruit of Zaqqum (56:52–53), followed by boiling water that exacerbates their suffering. Tabrisi notes the compounding nature of this punishment, emphasising that the scalding water (*al-hamim*) is imbibed immediately after ingesting the accursed tree, symbolising a layered retribution for persistent disbelief and moral corruption.

55.layer1:
In Surah Al-Waaqia, verse 55 paints a vivid image of the punishment awaiting those who reject truth and justice, describing how they "will drink as the drinking of thirsty camels" (فَشَٰرِبُونَ شُرْبَ ٱلْهِيمِ). This verse, revealed in the Meccan period, addresses the fate of the "companions of the left" – those condemned for their arrogance and denial of divine guidance. The Arabic term *al-hīm* (الهيم) refers to camels suffering extreme, prolonged thirst in desert conditions, evoking an image of frantic, desperate drinking. Here, the verse metaphorically describes the torment of the hereafter, where the guilty will be forced to consume boiling water (as clarified in other Quranic verses like 56:54) that neither quenches thirst nor relieves suffering, mirroring the futility and agony of their worldly disobedience.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains this imagery as a warning against spiritual heedlessness. The "thirsty camels" symbolize insatiable worldly desires that, if left unchecked, lead to eternal regret. Historically, this verse challenged the materialistic mindset of pre-Islamic Arabia, where immediate gratification often overshadowed moral responsibility. The word *shāribūn* (شاربون), meaning "drinkers," emphasizes active participation in sin, highlighting human accountability.

For modern Muslims, this verse serves as a timeless reminder to balance worldly life with spiritual vigilance. It urges self-reflection: Are we, like the *hīm*, consumed by endless cravings for wealth, status, or pleasure, neglecting our higher purpose? Practically, it calls for gratitude for blessings like clean water – a resource many lack today – and encourages charitable action. By cultivating *taqwa* (God-consciousness) and moderation, we avoid becoming enslaved to transient desires, aligning our "thirst" with the eternal sustenance of faith and righteous deeds. The imagery also underscores Islam’s holistic justice: just as the righteous are promised boundless joy, the unjust face consequences mirroring their moral choices.
55.layer2:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:55), the phrase "drinking as the drinking of thirsty camels" (فَشَٰرِبُونَ شُرْبَ ٱلْهِيمِ) presents a vivid eschatological metaphor for the punishment of disbelievers in the hereafter. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize both its literal and symbolic dimensions, rooted in Arabic linguistic nuance and theological principles. The term *al-him* (الهيم) refers to camels afflicted by extreme thirst, a condition causing them to drink uncontrollably yet remain unsatisfied—a fitting analogy for the spiritual and physical torment of those who rejected divine guidance.

Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* explains that this imagery underscores the futility and agony of the disbelievers’ punishment: just as a parched camel’s drinking brings no relief, their consumption of scalding water (mentioned in preceding verses) perpetuates their suffering. This aligns with the Quranic principle of *munasabat al-jaza’* (proportionality between deeds and recompense), wherein the punishment mirrors the spiritual drought caused by rejecting truth. Al-Tabrisi further notes that the verse’s placement within the surah’s tripartite structure—contrasting the rewards of the *sabiqun* (foremost believers), *ashab al-yamin* (companions of the right), and *ashab al-shimal* (companions of the left)—highlights the consequences of moral and theological choices.

Sayyid Muhammad Husayn Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this into a metaphysical framework, linking the verse to the Shia understanding of *‘adl* (divine justice). The unquenchable thirst symbolizes the soul’s alienation from its divine source when severed from the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt, whom Shia theology regards as the spiritual "water of life" (*ma’ al-hayat*). This interpretation resonates with narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who taught that the "thirst" of the damned stems from their rejection of the Imam’s wilayah (authority), leaving them eternally deprived of the "river of divine mercy."

The verse thus serves as a theological admonition, integrating eschatology with the Shia doctrine of imamate. It reinforces the principle that one’s acceptance or rejection of divine guidance—embodied in the Ahl al-Bayt—shapes both earthly existence and posthumous reality, a theme recurrent in Shia hadith literature and supplications invoking the intercession of the Imams.
55.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Waaqia’s vivid imagery of sinners drinking “as thirsty camels” (56:55) is increasingly interpreted through ecological, social, and psychological lenses. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir-e-Namoona*, notes that the verse critiques unrestrained consumption—both literal and metaphorical—drawing parallels to humanity’s exploitative relationship with natural resources. The “thirsty camel” (al-him) symbolizes insatiable desire, a theme echoed in modern critiques of consumerism and climate injustice. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to Imam Ali’s teachings on moderation, framing overconsumption as a spiritual disease that disrupts societal balance.  

Scientifically, the camel’s rapid rehydration—a survival mechanism in deserts—contrasts with human overindulgence in contexts of abundance. Researchers like Dr. Omid Safi highlight how this mirrors modern “affluenza,” where excess leads to psychological emptiness and environmental harm. Philosophically, the verse warns against treating finite resources as infinite, resonating with UN Sustainable Development Goals on water equity and responsible consumption.  

Socially, the imagery critiques global inequalities: 2.2 billion people lack safe drinking water while others overconsume. Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Al-Mustafa International University, link this to Christian teachings on stewardship and Buddhist principles of mindful consumption. The verse becomes a cross-cultural call for ethical resource distribution.  

In essence, contemporary Shia thought transforms this eschatological warning into a urgent ethical framework, urging believers to combat greed, address climate crises, and embody the Quranic balance (mizan) in personal and global systems. As Ayatollah Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari notes, “The camel’s thirst, once a desert reality, now mirrors humanity’s unsustainable thirst for growth at nature’s expense.
55.layer4:
In Surah Al-Waaqia, verse 55 paints a vivid image of the thirst of the damned, likening it to the desperate drinking of camels driven mad by drought. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound layers of meaning here, transforming this warning into a spiritual mirror. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that the "thirsty camels" (al-hīm) symbolise souls consumed by the fire of worldly attachment, eternally parched because they rejected the "water of wilayah" – the divine love and guidance of the Prophet’s Household. Just as a camel’s thirst grows more intense the more it drinks saltwater, those who prioritise materialism over spiritual truth will find their inner emptiness magnified despite transient worldly gains.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her), in her timeless sermon, reminded believers that the Qur’an’s verses are "a spring for the heart’s thirst." This verse, then, becomes a call to self-audit: What are we truly thirsting for? The Imams taught that the "drink" of the Hereafter is determined by the soul’s alignment with divine truth in this life. Those who distance themselves from the Imamah – the luminous chain of guidance – drink from a mirage, never reaching fulfilment. Conversely, Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha, "The thirst of the heart is quenched only by the water of divine knowledge," which flows through loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt.

Practical wisdom emerges: Regularly assess your spiritual "thirst." Do your actions and desires align with the cooling waters of the Qur’an and the Imams’ teachings, or do they mirror the frenzied, unquenchable craving of those lost in illusion? Strengthen your connection to the Imam of our time through supplications like Dua al-Ahd and conscious adherence to their ethical framework. Let every worldly desire pass through the filter of this verse’s warning, transforming base cravings into disciplined yearning for the Fountain of Kawthar – the eternal drink offered by the embrace of wilayah.

55.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Waaqia 55’s depiction of sinners drinking “as the drinking of thirsty camels,” Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur on its eschatological context as a vivid metaphor for the torments of the hereafter. Both traditions, as seen in Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, contextualise the verse within Quranic warnings about resurrection and divine justice, interpreting *al-hīm* (thirsty camels) as emblematic of insatiable, agonising thirst. Ibn Kathir and Qummi similarly stress the physical and spiritual desperation conveyed by the simile, aligning with classical Arabic imagery of camels afflicted by extreme drought.

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi focus on the literal-physical dimensions of hell’s punishments, often citing prophetic hadith to reinforce the sensory reality of divine retribution. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) and Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) integrate metaphysical reflections, linking the “thirst” to spiritual deprivation resulting from rejecting divine guidance. Tabatabai notably frames this as a manifestation of the soul’s self-inflicted alienation from truth, resonating with Shia theological concepts of *walaya* (allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt) as integral to spiritual fulfilment.

These distinctions reflect broader hermeneutical tendencies: Sunni exegesis often prioritises textual literalism and transmitted narratives, while Shia tafsir frequently incorporates the Imams’ teachings as interpretive keys. Historically, this stems from differing epistemological frameworks post the early Islamic period, where Shia scholarship developed a distinct reliance on the Imams’ divinely inspired insights. Both approaches, however, converge in using the verse to emphasise moral accountability, urging believers towards piety. The shared ethical imperative transcends methodological differences, illustrating how Quranic imagery serves multifaceted didactic purposes across traditions.

مذہبی زور سے تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ قربانی اور رازی جیسے سنی مبصرین جہنم کی سزاؤں کے لفظی جسمانی جہتوں پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، اور اکثر پیشن گوئی حدیث کا حوالہ دیتے ہیں کہ وہ الہی بدلہ لینے کی حسی حقیقت کو تقویت دیں۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ اسکالرز جیسے تبریسی (*ماجما البیان*) اور توسی (*ٹیبیان*) استعاریاتی عکاسیوں کو مربوط کرتے ہیں ، اور "پیاس" کو روحانی محرومی سے جوڑتے ہیں جس کے نتیجے میں الہی رہنمائی کو مسترد کیا جاتا ہے۔ تبتابائی نے خاص طور پر اس کو سچ سے روح کے خود سے دوچار بیگانگی کے مظہر کے طور پر فریم کیا ہے ، جو * والیاہ * (اے ایچ ایل البائٹ سے بیعت) کے شیعہ مذہبی تصورات سے گونجتے ہوئے روحانی تکمیل کے لئے لازمی قرار دیتے ہیں۔

یہ امتیازات وسیع تر ہرمینیٹیکل رجحانات کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں: سنی استثنیٰ اکثر متنی خواندہیت کو ترجیح دیتا ہے اور بیانات کو منتقل کرتا ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ طافس نے اکثر اماموں کی تعلیمات کو تشریحی چابیاں کے طور پر شامل کیا ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ ابتدائی اسلامی دور کے بعد مختلف ماہر نفسیاتی فریم ورک سے پیدا ہوتا ہے ، جہاں شیعہ اسکالرشپ نے اماموں کی الہامی طور پر متاثرہ بصیرت پر ایک الگ انحصار تیار کیا۔ تاہم ، دونوں نقطہ نظر اخلاقی احتساب پر زور دینے کے لئے آیت کو استعمال کرنے میں تبدیل ہوجاتے ہیں ، اور مومنین کو تقویٰ کی طرف راغب کرتے ہیں۔ مشترکہ اخلاقی لازمی طریقہ کار کے اختلافات سے بالاتر ہے ، جس میں یہ واضح کیا گیا ہے کہ کس طرح قرآنی منظر نگاری روایات میں کثیر الجہتی تدریجی مقاصد کی خدمت کرتی ہے۔
55.summary: As articulated in Tafsir al-Mizan, expands this into a metaphysical framework, linking the verse to the Shia understanding of *‘adl* (divine justice). In Surah Al-Waaqia, verse 55 paints a vivid image of the punishment awaiting those who reject truth and justice, describing how they "will drink as the drinking of thirsty camels" (فَشَٰرِبُونَ شُرْبَ ٱلْهِيمِ). This verse, revealed in the Meccan period, addresses the fate of the "companions of the left" – those condemned for their arrogance and denial of divine guidance. The Arabic term *al-hīm* (الهيم) refers to camels suffering extreme, prolonged thirst in desert conditions, evoking an image of frantic, desperate drinking. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that the "thirsty camels" (al-hīm) symbolise souls consumed by the fire of worldly attachment, eternally parched because they rejected the "water of wilayah" – the divine love and guidance of the Prophet’s Household. The imagery also underscores Islam’s holistic justice: just as the righteous are promised boundless joy, the unjust face consequences mirroring their moral choices.
55.layer2short: In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:55), the phrase "drinking as the drinking of thirsty camels" (فَشَٰرِبُونَ شُرْبَ ٱلْهِيمِ) presents a vivid eschatological metaphor for the punishment of disbelievers in the hereafter. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize both its literal and symbolic dimensions, rooted in Arabic linguistic nuance and theological principles. The term *al-him* (الهيم) refers to camels afflicted by extreme thirst, a condition causing them to drink uncontrollably yet remain unsatisfied—a fitting analogy for the spiritual and physical torment of those who rejected divine guidance.

56.layer1:
In Surah Al-Waaqia (56:56), Allah describes the fate of the righteous with the phrase *هَٰذَا نُزُلُهُمْ يَوْمَ ٱلدِّينِ* – "That is their accommodation on the Day of Recompense." The term *nuzul* (نُزُل) carries rich meaning, referring to a hospitable reception or provision prepared for honored guests. Here, it symbolises the divine welcome awaiting believers in the afterlife – not merely shelter, but a gift reflecting their spiritual status. *Yawm al-Din* (يَوْمَ ٱلدِّينِ), the "Day of Recompense," underscores Islam’s core principle of divine justice, where deeds are weighed and souls receive their due. Shia tafsir works like Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* emphasise that this verse follows vivid descriptions of Paradise, contrasting the eternal rewards of the faithful with the fate of deniers, reinforcing the Quran’s Meccan-era focus on resurrection and accountability.

Historically, this surah was revealed when early Muslims faced intense persecution in Mecca. Verses like this fortified their resolve by affirming that worldly suffering would be transcended through divine justice. The *nuzul* metaphor would have resonated deeply in Arab culture, where hosting guests was sacred, framing Paradise as the ultimate honour from the "Best of Hosts" (Allah). For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on life as preparation for this eternal hospitality. It challenges believers to align daily actions with the values rewarded on *Yawm al-Din*: sincerity, compassion, and justice. In a materialistic age, it reminds us that true success lies not in temporary gains but in earning Allah’s pleasure – a concept Shia teachings link to following the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, who exemplify the Quran’s ethical vision. By living consciously of this accountability, Muslims can navigate modern trials with spiritual purpose, viewing every moral choice as a step toward their ultimate *nuzul*.
56.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Waaqia 56 by situating the term "nuzul" (accommodation) within the Qur'anic framework of divine justice and recompense. He interprets "nuzul" as the definitive hospitality (ḍiyāfa) granted to souls on the Day of Judgement, contingent upon their earthly choices. Drawing from the linguistic root *n-z-l* (to descend), he emphasises that this "accommodation" is neither arbitrary nor metaphorical but a direct manifestation of divine decree shaped by human moral agency. For the righteous, this constitutes the "descent" of divine mercy, while for transgressors, it reflects the inevitable consequence of rejecting guidance—a duality central to Shia theodicy.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* corroborates this, noting that the verse’s abrupt shift from describing Paradise (verses 10-55) to this declaration underscores the inescapability of accountability. He cites narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq linking "nuzul" to the eternal abodes (dār al-qarār) mentioned in Surah Ghafir (40:39), stressing that one’s ultimate station is irrevocably fixed on this Day. Classical Shia exegesis universally ties this to the doctrine of *‘adl* (divine justice), wherein recompense aligns perfectly with deeds—a principle inseparable from the ontological role of the Ahl al-Bayt as guides to righteous action.

Theologically, this verse intersects with the Shia understanding of *ma‘ad* (eschatological return), affirming that temporal deeds crystallise into eternal realities. As articulated in traditions from the Imams, the "accommodation" encompasses not merely physical surroundings but the soul’s existential state—either proximity to divine light or alienation therefrom. Jurisprudentially, this reinforces the necessity of *walaya* (allegiance to the Imams) and adherence to the Sharia as prerequisites for securing favourable recompense, a stance harmonising ethical action with metaphysical truth. Thus, the verse epitomises the Shia worldview where cosmic justice, mediated through divine covenant and prophetic legacy, achieves its consummation.
56.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Waaqia (56:56) is often interpreted through lenses of cosmic justice and existential accountability. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames "nuzul" (accommodation) as a direct consequence of one’s ethical and spiritual choices, reflecting the Quranic principle of reciprocal justice (*al-jazā’ al-muḍāf*). Modern scholars like Sayyed Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah have expanded this, linking the "Day of Recompense" to present-day social inequities, arguing that systemic oppression and environmental exploitation distort humanity’s collective capacity to earn divine "hospitality" in the hereafter.  

Philosophically, thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect the verse to existential responsibility, noting parallels with modern ethics of sustainability: just as ecosystems demand balance, divine justice requires harmony between human actions and cosmic order. Scientific insights into climate collapse and resource scarcity amplify this urgency—our "accommodation" in eternity mirrors how we steward Earth’s resources today.  

Socially, the verse resonates with global crises: refugee displacement, economic disparity, and climate migration. Shia theologians like Dr. Liyakat Takim stress that the Quran’s eschatological imagery challenges societies to address these issues as *preludes* to divine reckoning. Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Christian liberation theology and Buddhist impermanence teachings, find common ground in linking temporal justice to transcendent accountability.  

In multicultural contexts, the verse’s emphasis on recompense critiques both hyper-individualism and structural apathy. As contemporary scholar Dr. Maria Dakake notes, the "Day of Recompense" isn’t merely futuristic—it’s a call to align today’s social systems with the equity embedded in divine law. For modern believers, this verse bridges spiritual aspiration with activism, urging a world where justice isn’t deferred but pursued as sacred duty.
56.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Al-Waaqia (56:56), Allah describes the divine hospitality awaiting the righteous as "their accommodation on the Day of Recompense." The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound layers of this "accommodation" (nuzul), teaching that it transcends physical provisions to embody the eternal fruits of spiritual allegiance (Wilayah) and divine recognition. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states, *"The hospitality of Paradise is but the light of love for us [the Ahlul Bayt], radiating upon the hearts of the faithful."* Here, "nuzul" symbolizes the soul’s eternal proximity to its Creator, facilitated by loyalty to the purified Guides.

Lady Fatimah (as) illuminates this truth in her famed sermon: *"The scales of justice on Qiyamah weigh the love of Ali (as) – it is the heaviest deed."* This underscores that the "accommodation" promised is not merely a reward for deeds, but the manifestation of one’s connection to the Imamah. The spiritual reality of this verse lies in recognising that every act of devotion – from prayer to charity – gains its value through conscious submission to the divinely appointed Imams. 

Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin (as) teaches in Al-Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya: *"O Allah, let my soul’s lodging be Your nearness, attained through the intercession of Muhammad and his Family."* Thus, the verse calls believers to internalise Wilayah as the foundation of their spiritual architecture. Practical guidance lies in daily renewing one’s pledge to the Imams through sincere supplications (dua), ethical conduct mirroring their teachings, and seeking knowledge that deepens understanding of their station. 

Ultimately, this "accommodation" is the soul’s eternal abode in the shadow of divine mercy – a mercy inseparable from love for those whom Allah has purified (33:33). As Imam al-Baqir (as) said: *"Our shi’a are those whose hearts host no doubt in our guardianship."* Let this verse remind us that our true "provision" for the Hereafter is nurturing unshakable certainty in the light of Ahlul Bayt.

سورہ الواقیہ (56:56) میں ، اللہ تعالٰی نے نیک لوگوں کو اس فقرے کے ساتھ بیان کیا ہے جس کے فقرے * hchaucava naُزُlaُchaumai kelaucumaumaf sildedanِ *-"یہ بازیافت کے دن ان کی رہائش ہے۔" اصطلاح * nzul * (nُزُl) کے بھرپور معنی ہیں ، جو معزز مہمانوں کے لئے تیار کردہ مہمان نوازی یا فراہمی کا حوالہ دیتے ہیں۔ یہاں ، یہ بعد کی زندگی میں مومنین کے منتظر الہی استقبال کی علامت ہے - نہ صرف پناہ ، بلکہ ایک تحفہ جو ان کی روحانی حیثیت کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ * یاوام الدین* (Yalafuaumala ٱlidenِ) ، "بدلہ لینے کا دن" ، اسلام کے الہی انصاف کے بنیادی اصول پر زور دیتا ہے ، جہاں اعمال کا وزن ہوتا ہے اور روحیں ان کی وجہ سے ملتی ہیں۔ شیعہ طافسر الامہ تبتابائی کے * المزان * کی طرح کام کرتی ہیں اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ یہ آیت جنت کی واضح وضاحتوں کی پیروی کرتی ہے ، جس میں وفاداروں کے دائمی انعامات سے انکار کرنے والوں کی تقدیر سے متصادم ہوتا ہے ، اور قیامت اور احتساب پر قرآن مجید کے دور کی توجہ کو تقویت ملتی ہے۔

تاریخی طور پر ، اس سورہ کا انکشاف اس وقت ہوا جب ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو مکہ میں شدید ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنا پڑا۔ اس طرح کی آیات نے ان کے عزم کو مضبوط بناتے ہوئے اس بات کی تصدیق کی کہ دنیاوی مصائب کو خدائی انصاف کے ذریعے عبور کیا جائے گا۔ * نوزول * استعارہ عرب ثقافت میں گہری گونجتی ہوگی ، جہاں مہمانوں کی میزبانی مقدس تھی ، جو جنت کو "بہترین میزبانوں" (اللہ) کی طرف سے حتمی اعزاز کے طور پر تیار کرتی تھی۔ عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت اس ابدی مہمان نوازی کی تیاری کے طور پر زندگی پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ یہ مومنوں کو چیلنج کرتا ہے کہ وہ روزانہ کے اقدامات کو *یاوم الدین *پر بدلہ دینے والی اقدار کے ساتھ سیدھ میں لائیں: اخلاص ، ہمدردی اور انصاف۔ مادیت پسندی کے دور میں ، یہ ہمیں یاد دلاتا ہے کہ حقیقی کامیابی عارضی فوائد میں نہیں بلکہ اللہ کی خوشنودی حاصل کرنے میں ہے - ایک تصور شیعہ تعلیمات اہل بیت کی رہنمائی پر عمل پیرا ہونے سے منسلک ہیں ، جو قرآن کے اخلاقی وژن کی مثال دیتے ہیں۔ اس احتساب کے بارے میں شعوری طور پر زندگی گزارنے سے ، مسلمان روحانی مقصد کے ساتھ جدید آزمائشوں پر تشریف لے جاسکتے ہیں ، اور ہر اخلاقی انتخاب کو اپنے حتمی *نوزول *کی طرف ایک قدم کے طور پر دیکھ سکتے ہیں۔
56.layer2_urdu:
*طافسیر المزان *میں ، الہامہ تبتابائی نے الہی انصاف اور بدلاؤ کے قرآنی فریم ورک کے اندر "نوزول" (رہائش) کی اصطلاح کی حیثیت سے سورہ الواقیہ 56 کو واضح کیا۔ وہ "نوزول" کی ترجمانی کرتا ہے کہ وہ فیصلے کے دن روحوں کو دیئے گئے قطعی مہمان نوازی (ḍiyāfa) کی حیثیت سے ، ان کے زمینی انتخاب پر مستقل مزاج ہے۔ لسانی جڑ * N-Z-L * (نزول کے لئے) سے ڈرائنگ کرتے ہوئے ، وہ اس بات پر زور دیتا ہے کہ یہ "رہائش" نہ تو صوابدیدی ہے اور نہ ہی استعاراتی ہے اور نہ ہی انسانی اخلاقی ایجنسی کے ذریعہ الہی فرمان کا براہ راست مظہر ہے۔ نیک لوگوں کے ل this ، یہ خدائی رحمت کا "نزول" تشکیل دیتا ہے ، جبکہ خطا کرنے والوں کے لئے ، یہ رہنمائی کو مسترد کرنے کے ناگزیر نتائج کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔

تبریسی کے * مجس البیان * اس کی تائید کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ آیت کا اچانک جنت (آیات 10-55) کو بیان کرنے سے اس اعلامیے سے احتساب کی عدم استحکام کی نشاندہی کی گئی ہے۔ انہوں نے "نوزول" کو "نوزول" کو ابدی مکف (40:39) میں مذکورہ ابودیس (ڈیر القارر) سے جوڑنے والے امام جعفر السادق کی روایات کا حوالہ دیا ہے ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہوئے کہ اس دن کسی کا حتمی اسٹیشن غیر منطقی طور پر طے ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ کی توثیق عالمی طور پر اس کو * ‘ADL * (الہی انصاف) کے نظریے سے جوڑتی ہے ، جس میں بدلہ اعمال کے ساتھ بالکل سیدھ میں رہتا ہے۔

56.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Waqi'a 56:56, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s eschatological context, identifying "nuzul" (accommodation) as divine hospitality for the righteous on Judgment Day. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize its contrast with the preceding verses describing hellfire, framing it as a manifestation of divine justice and mercy. Ibn Kathir and al-Tabtabai’s *Al-Mizan* similarly align in viewing "nuzul" as a reward proportionate to one’s deeds, reflecting Quranic principles of moral accountability.  

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Shia commentaries like *Tafsir al-Qummi* and *Majma al-Bayan* often link the verse’s blessings to the intercession of the Ahl al-Bayt, interpreting "nuzul" as a grace flowing through their spiritual authority. Al-Tusi’s *Al-Tibyan* contextualizes this within the Shia concept of *walaya*, where divine rewards are inseparable from allegiance to the Imams. Sunni scholars, while acknowledging intercession (*shafa'a*), prioritize God’s direct agency: Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi frame "nuzul" as an unmediated divine gift, with Al-Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* cautioning against attributing independent causal power to created beings.  

These distinctions reflect broader theological frameworks. Shia interpretations often integrate Imamology into eschatology, whereas Sunni exegesis emphasizes God’s transcendence and the Quran’s literal descriptions. Historically, these differences stem from early debates over religious authority post-Prophet Muhammad, with Shia thought centering on the Imams’ ontological role in cosmic justice.  

While both traditions agree on the verse’s core message—divine recompense for righteousness—their interpretive lenses shape devotional practices. Shia spirituality may emphasize seeking proximity to the Ahl al-Bayt for eschatological benefit, while Sunni practice focuses on individual adherence to Quranic injunctions. Such nuances underscore how shared Quranic principles are enriched by diverse hermeneutical traditions.
